entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 2 at 6:08PM PST until March 2 at 8:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of central California, including the following counties, Monterey and San Benito.
* WHEN...Until 800 PM PST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 608 PM PST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Salinas, Seaside, Marina, Boronda, Prunedale, Castroville, Moss Landing and Elkhorn. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monterey, CA; San Benito, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM PST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 2 at 7:03PM MST until March 3 at 6:00PM MST by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
Critical fire weather conditions this evening have diminished due to winds becoming weaker. A fire weather watch for Sunday remains for portions of western Kansas.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 027 Wallace, 028 Logan, 041 Greeley and 042 Wichita.
* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 6 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 2 at 7:01PM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
At 659 PM MST, Doppler radar was tracking intense snow showers along a line extending from Garrison to near Deer Lodge to Warm Springs. Movement was east at 10 mph.
HAZARD...Visibility one-half mile or less.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Low visibility could result in dangerous driving conditions. Roadways will become snow covered.
Locations impacted include... Deer Lodge, Garrison, Brock Creek, Blossburg, Avon, Racetrack, and Elliston.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 90 between mile markers 166 and 194. Highway 12 Garrison to MacDonald Pass between mile markers 0 and 26.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butte/Blackfoot Region

cap:parameter.value: Intense snow showers will impact portions of southeastern Powell County including Interstate 90 and US Highway 12 through 800 PM MST

entry.title: Snow Squall Warning issued March 2 at 6:59PM MST until March 2 at 7:45PM MST by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Cheyenne has issued a
* Snow Squall Warning for... Central Carbon County in south central Wyoming...
* Until 745 PM MST.
* At 657 PM MST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from 10 miles northeast of Separation Lake to near Sinclair to 9 miles southwest of Teton Reservoir, moving east at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Intense bursts of heavy snow. Gusty winds leading to blowing snow and visibility rapidly falling to less than one-quarter mile. Wind gusts up to 35 mph.
SOURCE...Radar and webcams.
IMPACT...Travel will become difficult and potentially dangerous within minutes.
This includes Interstate 80 in Wyoming between mile markers 205 and 243.
Locations impacted include... Rawlins, Hanna, Sinclair, Seminoe Campground, Seminoe Dam, Separation Lake, and Teton Reservoir.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Carbon, WY

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 2 at 7:49PM CST until March 3 at 7:00PM CST by NWS Dodge City KS
entry.summary:
...Wildfire Danger Diminishing This Evening...
Very dry air resides across much of southwest Kansas Saturday evening, with relative humidity ranging from 8-14%. However, southwest winds have decreased substantially after sunset, below red flag criteria. As such, the red flag warning for Saturday will be allowed to expire on schedule at 8 pm CST.
...RED FLAG WARNING WILL EXPIRE AT 8 PM CST /7 PM MST/ THIS EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY...
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 043 Scott, Fire Weather Zone 044 Lane, Fire Weather Zone 061 Hamilton, Fire Weather Zone 062 Kearny, Fire Weather Zone 063 Finney, Fire Weather Zone 064 Hodgeman, Fire Weather Zone 074 Stanton, Fire Weather Zone 075 Grant, Fire Weather Zone 076 Haskell, Fire Weather Zone 077 Gray, Fire Weather Zone 078 Ford, Fire Weather Zone 079 Edwards and Fire Weather Zone 080 Kiowa.
* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 8 percent.
* IMPACTS...Open fires can quickly burn out of control.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Scott; Lane; Hamilton; Kearny; Finney; Hodgeman; Stanton; Grant; Haskell; Gray; Ford; Edwards; Kiowa

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 2 at 7:22PM CST until March 3 at 6:00PM CST by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a Fire Weather Watch for very low humidity and strong winds, which is in effect from late Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 204 Eastern Panhandle/Crescent Lake NWR, Fire Weather Zone 206 Sandhills/Valentine NWR/Nebraska National Forest and Fire Weather Zone 208 Niobrara Valley/Fort Niobrara NWR/Samuel R McKelvie National Forest.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 12 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Highs ranging from the mid 40s in the northeast panhandle to the upper 50s in the eastern Sandhills.
* LIGHTNING...Not expected.
* IMPACTS...Any fire start will be capable of spreading rapidly and becoming very difficult to control.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 2 at 6:17PM MST until March 3 at 6:00PM MST by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 322, 325, 326, 332, AND 333...
.A cold front will cross the region Sunday and support gusty west winds as relative humidities drop to the teens across southwest and south central South Dakota. The combination and gusty winds and low relative humidities may lead to critical fire weather conditions again late Sunday morning and afternoon.

* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 14 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity will produce critical fire weather conditions.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity would produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fall River County Area; Custer County Plains; Pine Ridge Area; Haakon County Area; Badlands Area; Bennett County Area; Mellette and Todd Counties; Tripp County

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 2 at 8:17PM EST until March 7 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree National Park-Gadsden.
* WHEN...From this evening to early Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek. At 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the river become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake overlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet the river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EST Saturday the stage was 15.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:00 PM EST Saturday was 15.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 17.0 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Wednesday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calhoun, SC; Richland, SC

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued March 2 at 5:53PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVWBOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM SATURDAY UNTIL 11 PM SUNDAY
*WHAT... The Avalanche Danger will rise to HIGH (Level 4 of 5) on Saturday Night.
*WHERE... Flat Top Mountains, Gore Range, Grand Mesa, West Elk Mountains, Elk Mountains, and the Northern and Central Sawatch Range.
*WHEN... In effect from 11 PM Saturday, March 2 until 11 PM on Sunday, March 3.
*IMPACTS... Heavy snow and strong winds are creating dangerous avalanche conditions in the backcountry. Large and dangerous avalanches will be very easy to trigger. Avalanches will run naturally. They can run long distances.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended. Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
Pritchett
entry.cap:areaDesc: Grand and Battlement Mesas; Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains; Flat Tops; South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; Eastern Sawatch Mountains above 11000 Ft; Western Chaffee County Between 9000 and 11000 Ft

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 2 at 7:44PM EST by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
Areas of fog over Lake Erie this evening will advance inland from time to time, with reduction in visibility to a half a mile or less.
This patchy dense fog is expected to expand farther inland late this evening towards the inland hills.
Roadways impacted, but not limited to include: the New York State Thruway south of Hamburg, and Route 5 south of Lake View.
If you are driving, slow down and be on alert for other motorists. Low visibility shortens the amount of time you have to react to situations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chautauqua; Cattaraugus; Southern Erie

* WHAT...Widespread accumulating small hail expected. Small hail showers are sporadic but hail can last a long time on roadways.
* WHERE...Mendocino Coast.

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 2 at 1:36PM AKST until March 3 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...VERY COLD WIND CHILLS FOR THE KLONDIKE HIGHWAY...
.Northerly outflow winds will generate 25 mph sustained wind speeds and higher gusts for the Klondike Highway. These winds combined with temperatures as low as 9 below zero will cause wind chills to 35 below zero.
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills. Wind chills as low as 35 below zero.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Wind chill values are expected to fall to 35 below again after dark.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 2 at 2:22PM PST until March 3 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning above 3500 feet, heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 9 to 15 inches with up to 20 inches over high remote terrain through Sunday. For the Winter Storm Watch above 4500 feet, additional heavy snow. Potential for additional snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches possible between Monday and Tuesday.
* WHERE...For the Winter Storm Warning, elevations above 3500 feet in Western Siskiyou County. For the Winter Storm Watch, elevations above 4500 feet in Western Siskiyou County. This includes Etna Summit on Sawyers Bar Rd.
* WHEN...For the Winter Storm Warning, until 10 PM PST Sunday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Monday morning through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow showers will persist through this weekend with another low and frontal system hitting the area on Monday and Tuesday. Some snow will accumulate down to 500 feet through these events.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Siskiyou County

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued March 2 at 2:10PM MST by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Wildfire Smoke.
WHERE...northern portions of Bent County. Locations include, but are not limited to, Fort Lyon, Hasty, McClave, and areas near John Martin Reservoir State Park.
WHEN...1000 PM Saturday March 02 to 900 AM Sunday March 03
IMPACTS...Smoke from the Boggsville wildfire, located 2 miles southeast of Las Animas, will affect the advisory area through Saturday evening and into Sunday morning.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: If smoke is thick or becomes thick in your neighborhood you may want to remain indoors. This is especially true for those with heart disease, respiratory illnesses, the very young, and the elderly. Consider limiting outdoor activity when moderate to heavy smoke is present. Consider relocating temporarily if smoke is present indoors and is making you ill. If visibility is less than 5 miles in smoke in your neighborhood, smoke has reached levels that are unhealthy.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bent, CO

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY HEALTH ADVISORY FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE FROM 1000 PM SATURDAY UNTIL 900 AM SUNDAY

entry.summary:

Snow accumulations between 4 to 8 inches in Plumas, Sierra and western Lassen counties, and 1 to 3 inches along Highway 395 in Lassen county. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Lassen and, Eastern Plumas and Sierra Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. The strong winds and weight of snow on tree limbs may down power lines and could cause sporadic power outages. entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 2 at 2:41PM CST until March 3 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
...Very High to Extreme Fire Weather Conditions Sunday...
.Breezy southwest winds, low humidities, and record or near record warmth will all combine to produce very high to extreme fire weather conditions over portions of central and southeast Iowa from late Sunday morning into the afternoon. Winds may gust as high as 30 to 40 mph with relative humidities 25 percent or less during the afternoon. A few fires continue to be noted in satellite imagery today and fire weather conditions should worsen further into tomorrow.
The National Weather Service in Des Moines has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from 9 AM to 6 PM CST Sunday.
* AFFECTED AREA...Much of central and southeast Iowa, along and southeast of a line from Atlantic, to Boone, to Iowa Falls and Waterloo.
* WIND...Sustained southwest winds 20 to 25 mph with gusts 30 to 40 mph at times.
* HUMIDITY..As low as 20 to 35 percent during the afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Some counties already have burn bans in effect.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 2 at 8:39AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong front will bring blizzard conditions to the west coast Today. The worst conditions will be Saturday afternoon into this evening for the Yukon Delta and St. Lawrence Island. Southeast winds will ramp up from Shishmaref to Kotzebue to Point Hope Saturday night, bringing a brief period of very cold wind chills followed by snow and blowing snow on Sunday. Blizzard conditions are possible and winds may gust as high as 45 mph.
A second front will move across the west coast late Sunday into Monday bringing another round of snow and blowing snow,and SE winds gusting to 40 mph. Snow will also move into inland areas as well. Snow and blowing snow will linger into Tuesday as the front moves northward.
Residents are encouraged to stay up to date with the latest forecast at www.weather.gov/fairbanks and be prepared for upcoming winter weather.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Lower Yukon River

cap:parameter.value: Series of Fronts To Bring Snow, Wind, and Blowing Snow Saturday through Tuesday

* WHAT...The avalanche danger for the warning area will remain HIGH on Saturday March 2nd.

* WHAT...Avalanche Danger has risen to HIGH at all elevations this morning. Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected at least through Saturday, 3/2/24.
* WHERE...The eastern slopes of the Sierra Nevada mountain range between Virginia Lakes to the north to Bishop Creek to the south.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 2 at 1:49AM MST until March 3 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FOR MUCH OF CENTRAL AND EASTERN NM FROM 11 AM TO 7 PM MST TODAY DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FOR NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NM FROM 10 AM TO 7 PM MST SUNDAY DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...
.Southwest winds will strengthen today across central and eastern New Mexico as an upper level storm system approaches from the Great Basin. The combination of strong winds, single digit humidity, and above normal temperatures will increase the risk for critical fire weather conditions. Southwest to west winds will strengthen even further into Sunday with critical fire weather focused over eastern NM.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Plains (Zone 104), Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), Central Highlands (Zone 125), and East Central Plains (Zone 126) from 11 AM to 7 PM MST today and 10 AM to 7 PM MST Sunday.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...For today, southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph. For Sunday, southwest to west 35 to 45 mph with gusts near 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...6 to 11 percent today then 10 to 15 percent Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued March 1 at 7:13PM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
AVWRIW
* WHAT...The avalanche danger is expected to increase to High overnight. Intense snowfall rates and increasing winds will make natural avalanches likely and human-triggered avalanches very likely.
* WHERE... Northwest Wyoming including Togwotee Pass, the Teton, Snake River, Salt River, and Wyoming Ranges. Mountainous areas of southeast Idaho including the Webster, Preuss, Caribou, Snake River and Big Hole Ranges.
* WHEN...In effect until Midnight Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS... Heavy snowfall and strong winds will create dangerous avalanche conditions. Roof slides, and separate non- avalanche hazards like tree wells and snow immersion, are also likely.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Very dangerous avalanche conditions will develop tonight. The combination of intense snowfall and wind will create wind slabs that will be large and easy to trigger. Avalanche conditions will be most dangerous on slopes with windblown snow, but triggering a slide breaking on steep, sheltered slopes is also possible. Avoid terrain exposed to steeper slopes overhead, and avoid wind-loaded terrain. Human-triggered and natural avalanches are very likely. Avalanches may involve deeper, weak layers of snow and produce a larger avalanche than expected. Avalanches could run onto low angle terrain, hitting paths, roads or groomed snowmobile trails.
Consult bridgertetonavalanchecenter.org or avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Jackson Hole; Star Valley; Salt River and Wyoming Ranges

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued March 1 at 10:50AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Imperial County APCD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particulate matter from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect Saturday, March 2, 2024 and Sunday, March 3, 2024.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particulate levels: Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation Slow down if driving on dirt roads Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particulate matter can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Imperial County Southwest; Imperial County West; Imperial Valley
